Transcription: I appeal against the decision of the Local Tribunal on my claim for total exemption from military service on the following grounds (a) I am certain that my position as a conscientious objector to every department of military service was grossly misunderstood. I thought I made it absolutely clear to them that I cannot take any share in whatsoever is of the nature of an act of war. In my individual capacity I am quite prepared to give Queens, comfort or inspiration to whomever stands in need of it and to alleviate pain and suffering if the opportunity arises. This is in its very essence a Christian work. However, under no circumstances can I submit myself to military control & become part of the military organisation. Any such action of mine would deprive me of any power of initiative and individuality and would simply make me a part of the military machine. My religion, the highest ideals of my life, forbids me to sear absolute and unconditional allegiance to anyone except God himself. Therefore not to exempt me from all military service does not meet the claims of my conscience and I find it impossible to join the Royal Army Medical Corps P.T.O.

Tag: Unknown document type

Description: (B) The Local Tribunal persisted in ignoring or disregarding the importance of the preparation in which I am now engaged viz for the Christian Ministry - I am at present reading for Honours in Latin at the University of Wales and expect to finish this course next June. Furthermore as I am convinced that my vocation is to minister to the spiritual and the highest needs of men I feel that God has called me to perform this most important work. The Government has acknowledged the supreme importance of this work in exempting ministers of religion of any creed absolutely from any war service. In view of this I contend, sirs, that it is surely not even reasonable to refuse me the right to prepare myself for the selfsame work. Reasons: (I) It is absolutely impossible for me, as a Christian, to undertake service in the furtherance of the war on any terms whatever, by reason of my conception of the loyalty which I have sworn to the Lord Jesus Christ. In the light of His teaching, I am convinced that War, under any circumstances, and Christianity are diametrically opposed to one another. By "service in furtherance of the War", I mean that I cannot conscientiously take part in military service, nor in any employment necessitating the taking of the military oath, nor in the production of material, the object of which is the taking of human life. (II) My present work in College in preparing myself for the Christian Ministry, I regard as a work of supreme national importance. Surely it is in the best interests of the nation that its moral and spiritual well-being should be provided for! In view of the above reasons, I claim exemption in accordance with the provisions of the Military Service Act, 1916 [Clauses (f) and (c)].

Description: Letter to the Appeal Tribunal Cardigan

Transcription: Rock Villa, Dawley, Salop 22/3/16 Messrs The "appeal" Tribunal Cardigan. Gentlemen, I beg to write you re Mr W.J. Lewis, 2 South Marine Terrace, Aberystwyth (Student address), or Chapel St. Dawly, Salop (Home address), who is a member of the Horsehay Society in my circuit and a Mian worker and a prospective candidate for the missionary branch of the Mian ministry. Mr L. entered the Welsh university as a Salopian Scholarship student and is (deleted) in the second year of his arts course. But he is now definitely committed and pledged to the Mian ministry, especially work in 'India', on the completion of his career as first an Arts and then a theological student in either a special Missionary College or a general Theological Institute such as Mansfield College, Oxford, or Hartley College, Manchester. He is meantime an active member of the Christian Union of his University, and engaged from July to September, 1916, as assistant pastor or minister to the Dawley & Madeley Prim. Meth. circuit as per Directory enclosed. Such service being of vital & national importance, I trust he will be completely exempt from military duties, as that he may fulfil his pledges and engagements and realise his ideals. I know Mr Lewis is appealing against military (deletion) service on the ground of conscientious objections. I can vouch for the strength of his convictions and the sincerity of his motives, and I know the moral beauty & vigour of his character his deep devotion and sterling piety - that his pacifist principles would make it impossible for him to draw the sword or take

Name of Tribunal: Cardiganshire/Cardigan County

Tag: Unknown document type

Description: Continuation of Letter Appeal to Tribunal Cardigan

Transcription: up the rifle as a means of national defence. At the same time and notwithstanding his Christian convictions, I regard him as no less loyal a subject of his King & country than he is of the Kingdom of Heaven. In fact I have never met a youth of 20 who is a finer, more intelligent, more evenly balanced type of Christian character than Mr Lewis. I therefore, sincerely trust, gentlemen, that you may see the way clear to grant Mr L's request complete and permanent exemption from military service, so that he may pursue his career of study & service unhindered, for the benefit of his fellowmen and the country and empire he seeks to serve, as Mian minister & missionary. Transcription: CIRCUIT REGULATIONS. Preachers. All Preachers are affectionately requested to take their own appointments, and if unavoidably prevented, to obtain an accredited substitute. Preachers planned at Horsehay are planned at the Rock to send their hymns to Mr. W. Growcott by the previous Friday. Society Stewards. Society Stewards must supply written notices of services to be held and collections to be made; provision for the Lord's Supper, and attend to the general interests of the Society (Rule 186). They must fill up the Society Report Forms at the Quarterly Leaders' Meetings and forward the moneys to the Quarterly Meeting. Class Leaders. Each Leader must attend his Class as often as possible and impart useful spiritual instruction to his members, collect class and ticket moneys, and pay them in at the Quarterly Leaders' Meeting, furnish members on trial with Rules of Society, visit absentees and give suitable advice. Members. Members are expected to meet in class and regularly pay their contributions. In future no person shall be received as an approved Member who holds a license for the sale of Intoxicating Liquors. Removals. Members removing from the Circuit are kindly requested to apply to the Minister for a credential, or to notify their new address to their Leader. Baptisms. The Sacrament of Baptism can be administered at any ordinary service, except on Sunday evenings. Notice to be given previously to the Society Stewards. Fee for registration and certificate 6d.; if in the home, 1s. Legal Fee for searching Register and Certificate 2s, 7d. Marriages. The Madeley, Horsehay, Much Wenlock, & Beckbury Chapels are licensed for the solemnization of Marriages. For further information apply to the Ministers and the local Registrar. Funerals. In the event of the decease of any person belonging to any of our Churches or Sunday Schools, the friends having charge of the Burial are desired to arrange for our own Minister to conduct the Funeral Service. Forty-eight hours' notice must be given to the Clergyman or Clerk o fthe Burial Board. Books. Bibles, Hymn Books, Magazines, C.E., School and Band of Hope requisites, and Reward Books should be ordered from the Minister. Orders should be given not later than the 12th of the month, and accounts paid at least once a quarter. Grounds: I am aggrieved at the decision made by the Local Tribunal concerning my claim for exemption for the following reasons. First of all, I am confident that they have not understood my position as a conscientious objector to all military service. As I stated to them , I cannot participate in any act of war nor can i either take the military oath or allow it to be assumed that I have taken it. In my individual capacity, I am quite prepared to give comfort and inspiration to those in need of it and alleviate pain and suffering wherever the opportunity is given. This is, undoubtedly a Christlike work. But even for this work I cannot submit myself to military control and become part of military organisation, because this would take away from me all initiative and individuality and simply make me part of a machine. My conscience forbids me to give absolute and unconditional allegiance to any except God Himself. Thus, not b exempt me from all military service does not meet the claims of my conscience, and I find it impossible to enter the R.A.M.C. Another important matter that has been overlooked is my present work in College. I am now in the very middle of my College Career and am pursuing an Honours Course in History. Moreover, I realise that my call in life is to minister to the spiritual + religious needs of men. God has called me to the Highest task, to which it is possible to call a man. Is it reasonable to refuse me the right to prepare myself for the Christian ministry, a work undoubtedly of supreme national importance? Grounds: I appeal against the decision of the Local Tribunal re my case on the following grounds. (1) I am convinced that the Local Tribunal either misunderstood or deliberately disregarded my position as a conscientious objector to military service. In my appeal I thought I made it quite clear that I am not willing to take the military oath or allow it to be assumed that I have taken it since absolute allegiance to two different persons is impossible. I shall not partake in any work which is under military control and which is a deliberate act of war. My objections is not based on any political creed but on deep religious convictions. It is my deep rooted conception of the obedience I owe to no earthly (king) master, but to the King of Kings and to the Prince of Peace. Secondly, my work in preparing for the education of the rising generation is of the utmost importance. As one famous author says "Teachers touch the soul of the future" and so have the most to do in the moulding of the character of future citizens of Britain. This claim was ignored as the exemption certificate shows that the only ground taken into consideration was (f) the conscience clause. Therefore as a conscientious objector and being prepared for the teaching of the young, a work essentially of national importance, I think I am entitled to exemption.

Transcription: Ackworth School, Near Pontefract, 28 May 1916. Evan Evans Esq. Secretary of the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal. Dear Sir, I beg to acknowledge receipt of your notice that my appeal will be further considered at (deleted) next Friday June 2nd. In connection therewith I enclose a copy of a letter that I have received this morning from the Committee on work of National Importance from which I gather that the tribunal has communicated with them regarding my case. If they have decided to refer me to the committee, do you think they would be prepared to dispense with my appearance before them next Friday. I only suggest this as it seems possible that they may wish to refer any further evidence to the committee; but if they have any desire that I should attend I am quite prepared to do so, though my absence from the school for two or three days would cause some inconvenience. With regard to the enclosed I would like to point out that, I am at present engaged in teaching mathematics and science here, that I am a considerable distance from my home (Cardiff), and that I have accepted the post since sending in my appeal. I would be much obliged to you if you could let me have advice by wire as to whether I had better appear before the tribunal or not. I enclose a stamped form. In order to arrive in time I think I wold have to leave here on Thursday morning. I remain yours faithfully, Arthur E Williams

Description: Letter from Committee of National Importance, 26 Abingdon Street, Westminster S.W. Dated 27 May 1916 addressed to Mr Arthur Edward Williams, Ackworth School, Pontefract. Yorks.

Transcription: Dear Sir, Your application for assistance in obtaining work of national importance as the condition of your exemption from military service has been considered by the committee, but I am directed to inform you that without a personal interview they find it difficult to recommend work which you would be qualified to undertake. The committee would suggest for your consideration that you might take up work for the Y.M.C.A. or some teaching post. You will probably be able to communicate with some Education Authority on the subject. Failing this the committee could only recommend your employment on a farm or market garden where labour is really needed. In any case it is a stipulation of the Committee that the work must be at some distance, say over 20 miles from home, and it is necessary whatever work you undertake that you obtain and forward to the Committee a letter from your employer stating that he is willing to engage you, the nature of the work, and the remuneration. Description: To he Chairman, Of the Appeal Tribunal, Cardiganshire

Transcription: 17 Spring Gardens, Trefechan, Aberystwyth 22 June 1916 Sir I was granted four months exemption by the Local Tribunal at Aberystwyth from June 1st till the end of September 1916, and now the Military Representative is appealing against that order at the appeal Tribunal on the 23rd inst. I am employed by the Aberyswyth Corporation as Carter, and have worked for them for the last sixteen years. I would have appeared personally before you gentleman on Friday, but cannot afford the expense of Railway Fare, and a days wages which I would loose, so I ask you to please excuse me for not doing so. I am quite willing to do my bit for my Country, but as you will see by the enclosed Drs letter that my wife is very poorly, and I have got four young children, ages 7½, 6½, 4 years, and one 6 months old, and I hve nobody that I can ask in to help her, which means that I have to put in all my spare time to keep the home going. I am 40 years of age, and get cramp in my right leg very often, which was kicked by a horse a while go, so I hope you will please be kind enough under these circumstances to see your way clear to up-hold the Local Trinbunals decision. I am, Sirs, Your Obediently, John Hughes Edwards

Description: Letter from the British Dental Association highlighting a test case for the exemption of a dentist, which was allowed, and which should also include dental mechanics.

Transcription: British Dental Association, 19 Hanover Square, London W. 20th June 1916 Dear Sir I forward for your information and guidance the rider appended to a decision of the Central Tribunal with reference to the case of a dentist for whom an appeal was made by the Association. In the first instance, the dentist was granted merely a short postponement by the Local Tribunal; he appealed against this decision to the Appeal Tribunal, who, while declining to alter the decision, granted leave to appeal to the Central Tribunal. The Solicitors of the Association were instructed to endeavour to obtain permission for the Council to appear before the Central Tribunal on his behalf. This permission, however, was not granted and only a written appeal was allowed. A statement was accordingly drawn up on general principles in order that an appeal might be considered in the light of a test case, and the Association offered to depute one of its members to attend before the Tribunal to discuss the matter. This lead to an interview with the Executive Committee on June 2nd. The committee discussed the whole problem with the Central Tribunal from the point of view of National Interests and Public Health and also hardships of individual dentists. The appeal in the case referred to was allowed, and the dentist was granted exemption conditional upon his remaining in his present occupation, and the following important addition was appended to the decision :- "The Central tribunal from evidence submitted to them are impressed with the danger of further reducing the number of registered dentists now in the country. Whether nay particular dentist should be granted exemption must obviously depend to some extent upon the requirements of the place in which he practices, but they are inclined to think that unless it be shown that his services are not required he should be granted an exemption. Similar considerations apply to the mechanics on whom dentists depend for the efficient performance of their work." I trust that this pronouncement, coming as it does, from the Central tribunal, will be assistance to those who may be appealing for exemption, either on their own behalf of for their mechanics. Yours sincerely Frank J. Pearce Hon. Secretary

Description: attached reasons for Richard Ash's application as to exemption form

Transcription: My Laundry is the only Steam Laundry in or near to the County of Cardigan, and I do the Laundry work for all the Hotels and most of the Institutions (including the Red Cross Hospital) in and near to Aberystwyth, and there is no other Laundry available. The Capital invested in the Laundry amounts to £4000. Before the War three men were employed for indoor work, but now I only have this man left. It is absolutely necessary for the working of the Laundry that at least one man (experienced) should be employed upon indoor work to do the work of Boiler man Engine man and Wash-house man, where he has sole charge of the power plant and machinery including repairs as well as the daily working of the machinery. This work could not be done by a woman, because the plant includes a Boiler and Engine in addition to the Washing machines. On the 31st March 1916 Temporary Exemption was granted in respect of this man to the then proprietor of my Laundry, but there being then one other man at the Laundry to do the indoor work this man joined the Army about six weeks before his Exemption expired. On the 25th May 1916 this man was discharged from the Army "in consequence of being rejected by the Medical Board at Newport, Mon," he accordingly returned to the Laundry and the other man joined the Army. This man was on the 17th May last examined by the Recruiting Medical Board at Carmarthen and classified "A", Notwithstanding the fact that he remained in the same state of health as when previously examined (a Medical Certificate in regard to this will be produced to the Tribunal) This man is fully employed at the Laundry and I myself work from 6-30 a.m. till 8 or 9 p.m. and my Wife also devotes the whole of her time to the business in which I employ 25 women and girls. I submit that it is expedient in the National Interests that my Laundry should be allowed at least a minimum of one man to enable it to continue working, especially in view of the fact that the town and neighbourhood of Aberystwyth depend upon him for Laundry work in addition to the facts that I am such a large employer of labour and have such a large Capital at stake as are mentioned above, and that serious hardship would ensue if I were not allowed this one man inasmuch as the whole of my Capital is at stake.

Transcription: St John's College, Cambridge, 31st Oct 1917. To the Chairman of the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal Dear Sir, I understand that the ground on which the Military Appeal for the withdrawal of my certificate is being made, is that I should be compelled to submit to further medical examination. I should be much obliged if you would permit me to make the following statement with reference to the facts giving rise to the Appeal. During the vacation I received a notice calling me up for medical reexamination. About the same time my attention was drawn to the following cutting from "The Times" of July 13th 1917. "CERTIFIED EXEMPTIONS NOT LIABLE FOR RE-EXAMINATION At the House of Commons Appeal Tribunal yesterday Mr. D. Maclean, M.P., stated that after consultation with the authorities he was authorised to confirm his previous statement that a man holding a valid certificate of exemption under the Military Service Act, 1916, was not liable to be called up by the Army authorities for medical re-examination during the currency of his certificate, except in the case of a man who has never been examined and classified by an Army Medical Board. The same principle applied to an attested man in similar circumstances, the intention having been frequently expressed that an attested man was not to be placed at a disadvantage as compared with a non-attested man. There were some cases where a man had been rejected and held a certificate of exemption but was liable for re-examination, but on classification for any form of military service he started with fresh tribunal rights" As I held a Tribunal Exemption Certificate and had already been examined by a Medical Board (class B 3) I already fell within the lines of Mr Maclean's statement. I accordingly wrote to the Barry Recruiting Officer and pointed out that I was not liable to reexamination during the currency of my certificate. Transcription: Glanrhyd, Nantymoel, Glamorganshire, 26th Sept 1917. To the Chairman of the Aberystwyth Borough Tribunal Dear Sir, I shall be much obliged if you will lay before your Tribunal the following considerations with reference to the Military Appeal against my Exemption. 1. Since the outbreak of war I have been totally rejected on four ocasions (No 11th 1914; July 10th 1915; Nov 22nd 1915 and January 17th 1916) I served in the Officers Training Corps for some time but was then discharged on account of my physical unfitness. On each occasion the chief cause of my rejection was on permanent injury to the leg. On examination by a Medial Board I was classified as fit only for clerical work (B3). In view of the permanent character of the disablement as further testified by the attached medical certificate, there seems no ground for further examination 2. As I am in Class B3, I come under the Bd of Education Agreement with the War Office whereby all students under class B1 came to be exempted from service 3. I am being educated for the work of teaching and I am at present engaged in research work on industrial conditions - work which is of the highest importance at the present time. I propose going up to Cambridge next season and as I have already become a student of that University paid my fees it would be a serious financial loss if I was not allowed to proceed there. Description: Letter from Mr Roberts to the Clerk of the Aberystwyth Tribunal regarding Illtyd Davies' case at the meeting of the next Tribunal

Transcription: University College of Wales, Aberystwyth September 27th, 1917. To the Clerk of the Aberystwyth Tribunal. Dear Sir, Mr Illtyd David having informed me that his case is to come before the next meeting of the Tribunal I beg leave to submit the following statement in reference to his position. Mr David has studied in this College for four years and is a graduate of the University of Wales with first class Honours in Economics. During the Session 1916-1917 he continued the study of Economics as a Post-graduate Student, his special subject of investigation being "Industrial conditions and the methods of Industrial peace." At the close of the Session he went for the vacation to his home in the industrial district of Glamorgan having already arranged to proceed for the coming Session to the University of Cambridge for the further prosecution of his special studies. Description: Application for exemption from military service.

Transcription: 3 Rheidol Place, Aberystwyth, 4th March 1918. Gentlemen, I beg to apply to you for leave to re-hear my application for exemption from military service. On the 29th August 1916 I appeared before you on an appeal by the Military Representative against the temporary exemption granted to me by the Abersytwyth Borough Tribunal when the appeal was allowed on an undertaking being given that I should not be called up before the 16th October 1916 with an intimation from the military that if I joined the mercantile marine before that date, they would not further trouble me. I have been engaged as a deep sea Fisherman at Aberystwyth since 1904 and am an experience Fisherman with an intimate knowledge of the fishing grounds of Cardigan Bay, and I am now desirous of resuming my occupation as a fisherman. Since my last appearance before you, I have been engaged in the Mercantile Marine as a Seaman. I have now been requested by the Aberystwyth Town Council to resume my occupation as as fisherman with a view to increasing the food supplies of the Town and district and if my application is granted, it is intended that I should enter into an arrangement with the Abersytwyth Town Council for the sale of all my catches of fish at Aberystwyth at a fixed price fro the benefit of the inhabitants of the Town and district. I am 41 years of age, married, and have been rejected for the Royal Naval Reserve upon voluntary enlistment since the present War commenced as being unfit on medical grounds. As the fishing grounds of Cardigan Bay are at present teeming with fish, an abundant food supply is waiting to be utilised and in view of the present shortage of food, I beg to submit that my exemption by you from military service would materially assist in increasing the food supply of the district and would enable me to serve the national interest in the very best possible way at the present time having regard to my exceptional qualifications as an expert fisherman. I am, Gentleman, Your obedient servant, J H Thomas

Description: Letter from P.D.S. Vokes' employers (George Anderson and Andersons_ to the Clerk to the Aberystwyth Borough Tribunal

Transcription: Please address all communications to the firm writing separate letters on seperate subjects. Please quote our reference. AGP/CH. GEORGE ANDERSON & ANDERSONS. COLLIERY PROPRIETORS. TIMBER MERCHANTS. TELEGRAMS: "YEDDA PHONE, LONDON." TELEPHONES: GERRARD 644 645 (TRUNKS) Empire House, 175 & 176, Piccadilly. London W.1 12th July 1918. To: - The Clerk to the Tribunal, Dear Sir, RE Percy David Smerdon Vokes. of 73 North Parade, Aberystwyth. Should your Tribunal see their way to grant this man exemption if he obtains work of National Importance, we have the honour to state that he is working for us at the present time as a foreman of timber hauliers. Owing to this previous experience in the timber trade in Canada he is a very useful man for this purpose, and we should find it difficult to adequately replace him. Most of the timber which he is engaged in hauling is being consigned to collieries for use as pit props, and we probably need not point out that this is work of the greatest possible national importance, inasmuch as it is impossible to obtain coal without pit props, and that, therefore, every branch of munition work must obviously be affected by the supply of pit props being maintained. We are, Dear Sir, Yours faithfully, per pro George Andersn & Andersons A.G.P.

Transcription: A. BENNETT - Dear Sir, The above man has been employed by the above Association as a Timber Loader, up to the 3rd. August, when he was given leave until the end of August. It is extremely difficult to get suitable loaders at present and I trust you will be able to grant his Conditional Exemption. Yours faithfully, Vincent W. Evans, District Manager.
